title: need help with flipping the bit

forumNotes.author: Zoso
forumNotes.content:
hi everyone, I have a kingston data traveler 16gb flashdrive that I boot xp/usboot from first partition but I have two more primary partitions on it and these can not be recognised in other computers and I would like to access these from other computers without having to boot the first partition, just access them as normal USB access. I have ran chip genius but I need help selecting the correct program to "flip the bit" because I am having trouble with translations from chinese and russian languages to english and I find more than one option for this flashdrive. most importantly, is there any possibility that I can render this flashdrive useless/beyond recovery if I use the wrong program while trying to flip the bit?
here are the details I get from chip genius: Device Name: ++USSB Mass Storage Device(KingstonDataTraveler 2.0 USB Device) Chip Vendor: skymedi Chip Part-Number: SK6281/SK6211 VID: 0951 PID: 1603
my confusion stems mostly from the part number since it is a dual part number divided with a slash and these part numbers each have a different program for flipping the bit according to this site shown/linked in chip genius: [http://bbs.mydigit.c...ad.php?tid=4345](http://bbs.mydigit.cn/read.php?tid=4345 "External link")
can anyone help clear up my confusion on this and also, is there any danger in trying the lexar tool on this to see if it works? in other words, if the lexar tool doesnt work will it do nothing or do irreversable damage? Im still reading translations but I wanted to ask here also. I will post if I find the answer and have success. thanks

forumNotes.author: tummychow
forumNotes.content:
You want to flip the removable/fixed disk bit right? I believe the right utility for that is BootIt (the lexar one that you're thinking of); forget where I downloaded it but it's around here somewhere on this forum.  
I have never used or needed to use bootit; it basically wipes the disk in the process but it should be reversible; can't speak from experience. That being said, there's always weird risks. The first time I tried to use syslinux on my old kingston datatraveler (first generation 16gb), rmprepusb reformatted it and it crashed. The disk ended up going into hardware read only mode and I had to rma it (thank the heavens for 5yr warranty).

forumNotes.author: Wonko the Sane
forumNotes.content:
I don't think that the Lexar boot-it is compatible with Skymedi controllers ![:cheers:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/cheers.gif) (but may be proved wrong anytime ![:cheers:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/cheers.gif)) Let's disambiguate the side issue about RMPREPUSB: it is NOT possible that RMPREPUSB damaged in such a way a stick, what happened was a mere coincidence (or collision) i.e. the stick decided to go to whatever heaven good USB sticks are deemed to go at the same time you used RMPREPUSB, at the most the "stress" caused by repartitioning/reformatting/wiping/imaging "initiated" the failure, but any other program capable of doing the same things would have caused the death of your stick ![:ph34r:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/scared9.gif) (may it R.I.P. ![:happy_dance:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/celebrate14.gif) ) @zoso Controllers usually go in "families". In other words you are looking for utilities aimed to the "SK62XX" family. When multiple of such utilities are present, rule of the thumb is: * get latest version * see if you can make head or tail of the actual contents/utility * get previous version * see if it has additional files/docs/pictures/whatever * see if you can make head or tail of the actual contents/utility * get previous version * etc. as it can happen that previous version ***x*** has more documentation than later version ***y*** . So, use the actual program from latest version BUT see if you can learn more by the "whatever more" that can ***maybe*** be found in "older releases" BEFORE attempting to actually run the tool. Here: [http://flashboot.ru/...es\&op=cat\&id=12](http://flashboot.ru/index.php?name=Files&op=cat&id=12 "External link") in any case the "manufacturer utility" should be capable to identify exactly the controller and use (internally and in "stealth mode" or openly) the "right" set of commands for the specific controller or simply say that the target is "not right" (and you need to get another version of the tool). Just for the record, read these (about Lexar utility, but not only): [http://www.911cd.net...showtopic=21850](http://www.911cd.net/forums//index.php?showtopic=21850 "External link") [http://www.911cd.net...showtopic=21697](http://www.911cd.net/forums//index.php?showtopic=21697 "External link") [http://www.911cd.net...showtopic=15923](http://www.911cd.net/forums//index.php?showtopic=15923 "External link")
![:ph34r:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/scared9.gif) Wonko

forumNotes.author: Zoso
forumNotes.content:
from more translating/reading at flashboot.ru I found mention that the chip genius program may not determin the exact chip correctly so I opened up the case and indeed found a different chip than what both chip genius and usbdeviceview were reporting.  

the chip is an sss6690, this one: [http://wiki.flashboot.ru/SSS6690](http://wiki.flashboot.ru/SSS6690 "External link")  

I can not understand what is needed to do in the program they have suggested for the sss6690 to flip the bit though. here are some screen caps:  

the main screen: ![Posted Image](http://www.pixentral.com/pics/10brEjWGyPPKsY6TtPndPhErY0AJMx.jpg)  

and this is after clicking the set up button: ![Posted Image](http://www.pixentral.com/pics/1Fkx9IXHVVMsyqJ3sXC1Ooh6k0lIGE.jpg)  

any suggestions? I'll read from the links you have provided, thanks

forumNotes.author: Wonko the Sane
forumNotes.content:
Good. :smile: Now you need to get the general idea. You are going to send to a small amount of "static memory" inside the actual controller's chip some data, or if you prefer you are going to set the values for a number of variables stored in the controller firmware. Usually these values are kept in a .ini file and can be "loaded" from it and "saved" to a new .ini. So a very good idea is to first thing create your own .ini file by saving the whatever is currently loaded to a new .ini. Then make changes and save on the same until you are perfectly satisfied with what you see BEFORE hitting the button. Which actual tool are you trying to use? This one? [http://www.flashboot...s-file-437.html](http://www.flashboot.ru/Files-file-437.html "External link") from the screenshots it doesn't look like you have in that the \*needed\* settings.
The "right" ones should be these: [http://www.flashboot...s-file-567.html](http://www.flashboot.ru/Files-file-567.html "External link") [http://www.flashboot...ew_file\&lid=502](http://www.flashboot.ru/index.php?name=Files&op=view_file&lid=502 "External link") [http://www.flashboot...s-file-441.html](http://www.flashboot.ru/Files-file-441.html "External link") etc. ![:unsure:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/unsure.png) Jolt down this number: 5526568 ![:cheers:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/cheers.gif) This tool is particularly "complex" (when compared to other ones I have seen), and I seem NOT finding any useful documentation about it's actual use. Don't ***EVEN THINK*** to use it with the actual stick until some minimal idea on how it works is found. ![:ph34r:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/scared9.gif) Start reviewing the values in .ini files, do compare the .ini coming with different versions of the MP tool. Try running the utility with different values given to variable "Setting_Mode" in Mpt1.ini. The setting you want to have is (probably) "Passid, bootable, partitionable" ![:thumbsup:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/thumbsup.gif) but the utlility seems like ALSO and at the same time sending the actual firmware (one of the .bin files) and if you get the wrong one it is possible that you may need to kiss your stick goodbye! ![:w00t:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/w00t.gif) Possibly one of the "Setting_Mode" values only sends the different values without also replacing the firmware. ![:ph34r:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/scared9.gif) ![:cheers:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/cheers.gif) Wonko

forumNotes.author: ambralivio
forumNotes.content:
@ Zoso,  

I've not such an expertize, but it seems that the utility you are using is not the most indicated for your target.  

I'd try the other one, SecureAP, but the short instructions say this will only create 2 partitions.  

If I'm right, this is the typical situation of U3 technology (the first partition, active, has a CDFS filesystem, accessible through a password, and the second at your choice)   

My advice, but without offense at all...... it's not a job for noobies, as several times recommended.....  

ambralivio

forumNotes.author: Wonko the Sane
forumNotes.content:
> I'd try the other one, SecureAP, but the short instructions say this will only create 2 partitions. Naah, SecureAP should have another approach, two "partitions", one "freely viewable/accessible", the other "password protected". But this is made by having two LUN's, i.e. two devices or disks, see picture: [http://www.flashboot...s-file-364.html](http://www.flashboot.ru/Files-file-364.html "External link") each with one partition in it. This is what makes me perplexed the most, it is possible that the mentioned "Passid, bootable, partitionable" makes this kind of setup (that is of no actual use, as the "removable bit" won't likely be "flipped"). U3-like is yet a bit different, you still have two LUNs or devices, but the first one is a CD-like one and the second a HD-like one.
![:thumbsup:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/thumbsup.gif) Wonko

forumNotes.author: ambralivio
forumNotes.content:
> U3-like is yet a bit different, you still have two LUNs or devices, but the first one is a CD-like one and the second a HD-like one. > >
> > ![:thumbsup:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/thumbsup.gif) > Wonko That is just what I stated in my reply.............(please, Wonko, read my mail with the due diligence). My experience/knowledge (not so great as yours) says that in most of the cases (read most controllers) where U3 type is used, like in this case (I seem), the controller does not permit "to flip the bit". At this point, as I saw there's no utility for the above operation for that controller, are we sure the bit is effectively flippable ? ambralivio

forumNotes.author: Wonko the Sane
forumNotes.content:
> That is just what I stated in my reply.............(please, Wonko, read my mail with the due diligence). > > My experience/knowledge (not so great as yours) says that in most of the cases (read most controllers) where U3 type is used, like in this case (I seem), the controller does not permit "to flip the bit". Sure ![:ph34r:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/scared9.gif) I was trying to expand on your point, as you have it IMHO *mostly* ![:thumbsup:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/thumbsup.gif) (but NOT *exactly* ![:ph34r:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/scared9.gif)) right. (according to what I have seen, which still is not necessarily "100% exact") U3 is mostly a commercial name of a particular setup, what I am trying to say is: * There are controllers capable of showing a single device. (floppy/HD-like) * There are controllers capable of showing two devices.(BOTH floppy/HD-like) * There are controllers capable of showing two devices.(one floppy/HD-like and one CD/DVD like)
In sticks based on controller type #1 above there may be a MPtool (like the SecureAP) that can create on the **same** device two partitions, one password protected one "normal", in this case in Disk Management you see the same Disk, but with two partitions in it. In sticks based on controller type #2 above there may be a MPtool (like the SecureAP) that can create **two** separate devices, each with one partition, one password protected, one "normal", in this case in Disk Management you see two Disks. In sticks based on controller type #3 above there may be a MPtool that can create **two** separate devices, one floppy/hd-like, the other CD/DVD like in this case in Disk Management you see **one disk** and **one CD/DVD** . These sticks can be U3 (but can also have the two devices without being "U3"). U3 sticks do NOT have two "partitions", they have two "devices" or two LUN's. Compare with: [http://www.911cd.net...showtopic=14564](http://www.911cd.net/forums//index.php?showtopic=14564 "External link") [http://www.msfn.org/...to-udf-or-cdfs/](http://www.msfn.org/board/topic/121199-formating-a-usb-stick-to-udf-or-cdfs/ "External link") ![:cheers:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/cheers.gif) Wonko

forumNotes.author: ambralivio
forumNotes.content:
> \[\*\]There are controllers capable of showing a single device. (floppy/HD-like)  
> \[\*\]There are controllers capable of showing two devices.(BOTH floppy/HD-like)  
> \[\*\]There are controllers capable of showing two devices.(one floppy/HD-like and one CD/DVD like)  
> \[/list\]  

Good clarifications ![:thumbsup:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/thumbsup.gif) ![:ph34r:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/scared9.gif) even if IMHO not so exhaustive.  

If we consider the "famous bit flippable" Lexar sticks (with BootIt tool), how can you classify their controller ?  

1. Surely NO  
2. Maybe (even if the bootable one is password protected ?)  
3. NO, because in this case the bootable partition is the CD-like one  

Besides, coming back to my question, and just to support Zoso, : are we sure that his stick has a flippable bit ?  

ambralivio

forumNotes.author: Wonko the Sane
forumNotes.content:
> If we consider the "famous bit flippable" Lexar sticks (with BootIt tool), how can you classify their controller ? See here: [http://www.911cd.net...showtopic=21850](http://www.911cd.net/forums//index.php?showtopic=21850 "External link") The utility is definitely compatible with SMI 321/324 chips (the report with Alcor is not IMHO "100% sure" ![:thumbsup:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/thumbsup.gif) , as I have seen reports about two EXACTLY same sticks, same brand, model, VID/PID, bought in the same shop, having upon inspection a different controller inside - just like it is happening here) It is very likely that newer SMI chips are still compatible with the Lexar tool. The corresponding SMI tool has a a setting for either: * Mode A (Public+security) \<- which should "translate" to 1 LUN/two partitions of which one "secure" * Mode C (Public+Public/security) \<- which should "translate" to 2 LUN's, one "normal", andopther one (optionally) "secure"
One for: * "USB-ZIP" \<- which should "translate" to "Removable" * "USB-HD" \<- which should "translate" to "Fixed"
And additionally, has a setting for: * "Reserve zone" and "Static CDROM size" which should "translate" to 2 LUN's, one CD-like, the other HD-like.
These are type #3, but you seem like having missed ![:ph34r:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/scared9.gif) the "telescopic nature" of the classification: Any of type #3 is also of type #2 and of type #1 Any of type #2 is also of type #1 But this is about the ***capabilities*** of the controller, and not necessarily means that "we" can use them or all of them. ![:ph34r:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/scared9.gif) (see below) > Besides, coming back to my question, and just to support Zoso, : are we sure that his stick has a flippable bit ? Yes/no. Meaning that I am pretty sure that \*any\* controller has this setting, but not necessatily the tools "we" have available for it can flip the bit, and not necessarily we actually know how to use the tool (IF it can do it) to do it. ![:cheers:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/cheers.gif) Wonko

forumNotes.author: Zoso
forumNotes.content:
> Good. :smile: > Now you need to get the general idea. > You are going to send to a small amount of "static memory" inside the actual controller's chip some data, or if you prefer you are going to set the values for a number of variables stored in the controller firmware. > > Usually these values are kept in a .ini file and can be "loaded" from it and "saved" to a new .ini. > > So a very good idea is to first thing create your own .ini file by saving the whatever is currently loaded to a new .ini. > Then make changes and save on the same until you are perfectly satisfied with what you see BEFORE hitting the button. sort of if not exactly like reflashing the firmware I take it? I have some experience in this area with other hardwares but I have allways been able to find precise documentation in my native language to follow. > Which actual tool are you trying to use? > > This one? > [http://www.flashboot...s-file-437.html](http://www.flashboot.ru/Files-file-437.html "External link") > from the screenshots it doesn't look like you have in that the \*needed\* settings. > >
> > The "right" ones should be these: > [http://www.flashboot...s-file-567.html](http://www.flashboot.ru/Files-file-567.html "External link") > [http://www.flashboot...ew_file\&lid=502](http://www.flashboot.ru/index.php?name=Files&op=view_file&lid=502 "External link") > [http://www.flashboot...s-file-441.html](http://www.flashboot.ru/Files-file-441.html "External link") > etc. > ![:unsure:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/unsure.png) >
Im not trying to use one yet only trying to learn which one to try and it is proving to be complicated by the language barrier.
> Jolt down this number: 5526568 :wink: >
OK, but why? > This tool is particularly "complex" (when compared to other ones I have seen), and I seem NOT finding any useful documentation about it's actual use. > > Don't ***EVEN THINK*** to use it with the actual stick until some minimal idea on how it works is found. ![:cheers:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/cheers.gif) > > Start reviewing the values in .ini files, do compare the .ini coming with different versions of the MP tool. > > Try running the utility with different values given to variable "Setting_Mode" in Mpt1.ini. > > The setting you want to have is (probably) "Passid, bootable, partitionable" ![:eek:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/eek.gif) but the utlility seems like ALSO and at the same time sending the actual firmware (one of the .bin files) and if you get the wrong one it is possible that you may need to kiss your stick goodbye! ![:w00t:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/w00t.gif) > > Possibly one of the "Setting_Mode" values only sends the different values without also replacing the firmware. ![:confused1:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/confused1.gif) > > ![:cheers:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/cheers.gif) > Wonko
particularly "complex"... yes, as is usually the case with everything I try to learn.
Ive found more info and softwares for the sss6690 and other USB controllers related to bit flipping. I will add some links Ive found that may help others: this one has info and links to download related software for most controllers: [http://zedany.com/t37567/?language=id](http://zedany.com/t37567/?language=id "External link") this is specific to SSS controllers with ID specifics and other helpful info: [http://babelfish.yah...TrUrl=Translate](http://babelfish.yahoo.com/translate_url?doit=done&tt=url&intl=1&fr=bf-home&trurl=http%3A%2F%2Fbbs.wuyou.com%2Fviewthread.php%3Faction%3Dprintable%26tid%3D155931&lp=zh_en&btnTrUrl=Translate "External link") another for SSS 6690 info: [http://babelfish.yah...TrUrl=Translate](http://babelfish.yahoo.com/translate_url?doit=done&tt=url&intl=1&fr=bf-home&trurl=http%3A%2F%2Fbbs.wuyou.com%2Fviewthread.php%3Ftid%3D144719&lp=zh_en&btnTrUrl=Translate "External link") and here is download links with minor documentation for sss6690: [http://babelfish.yah...TrUrl=Translate](http://babelfish.yahoo.com/translate_url?doit=done&tt=url&intl=1&fr=bf-home&trurl=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.dzdu.com%2Fhtml%2F17152.html&lp=zh_en&btnTrUrl=Translate "External link") Ive just downloaded all the softwares for the sss6690 and now I will extract and browse them to see if I can make anything of it. there is mention that some of these will flip the bit but I am unsure yet if the interface is only chinese. I will report back what I find. > @ Zoso, > > I've not such an expertize, but it seems that the utility you are using is not the most indicated for your target. > > I'd try the other one, SecureAP, but the short instructions say this will only create 2 partitions. > > If I'm right, this is the typical situation of U3 technology (the first partition, active, has a CDFS filesystem, accessible through a password, and the second at your choice) > > My advice, but without offense at all...... it's not a job for noobies, as several times recommended..... > > ambralivio hi ambralivio, thanks for the advice. we were all noobies at some point right? I may not be sucessful flipping this bit here but I wont attempt it unless I feel certain it will work. your next few posts after this one with Wonko has added alot of info that is very helpful to me so thanks again for posting here. Wonko is "The Man", I have learned more from his post here and elsewhere than anyone else and most often he is one that replys to questions directly. I am starting to lose count of how many things Ive been able to learn from him. Im glad he continues to post here after the reboot because I am not a member at any of the other forums that are frequently linked here only a lurker. before I leave to browse through these new programs here is a couple of more links relating to the sss6900 so that I can keep them handy and maybe usefull to others [http://babelfish.yah...TrUrl=Translate](http://babelfish.yahoo.com/translate_url?doit=done&tt=url&intl=1&fr=bf-home&trurl=http%3A%2F%2Fbbs.wuyou.com%2Fredirect.php%3Ffid%3D49%26tid%3D142465%26goto%3Dnextnewset&lp=zh_en&btnTrUrl=Translate "External link") [http://forum.soft-ce...pic.php?p=19400](http://forum.soft-center.ru/viewtopic.php?p=19400 "External link") [http://bbs.mydigit.c...e/?t173242.html](http://bbs.mydigit.cn/simple/?t173242.html "External link")
thanks again

forumNotes.author: Wonko the Sane
forumNotes.content:
> OK, but why? Try (with NO USB device connected) to hit the "Settings" button in any of the thingies numbered 2.1xx. Hit the "Password" button. What you could type in the opened popup? ![:unsure:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/unsure.png) Hint: your bithday date and your pet name won't work. ![:cheers:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/cheers.gif)
> and here is download links with minor documentation for sss6690: [http://babelfish.yah...TrUrl=Translate](http://babelfish.yahoo.com/translate_url?doit=done&tt=url&intl=1&fr=bf-home&trurl=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.dzdu.com%2Fhtml%2F17152.html&lp=zh_en&btnTrUrl=Translate "External link") This actually has a bit of information that may prove interesting ![:eek:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/eek.gif) The : > \[DISK\] > DiskSetting=U plate floppy disk hypothesis > MaxDiskSize= maximum capacity > FixedDiskSize= fixed capacity > AutoDiskSize= automatic fixed capacity > UpLimitAutoDiskSize= has the upper limit maximum capacity > **ReservedBlock= establishes the spare block number > DOSVolume= floppy disk volume sign** > ShowResultBIN= demonstrates the test result BIN seems like promising. ![:cheers:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/cheers.gif) It seems like the babelfish translation of the SIMPLE_Ultranet.ini, which is clearly the translation in Chinese of the interface, just remove the ; before "SIMPLE_UltraNet.ini" in MP6690.ini: ``` [LANGUAGE] ;FILE=CHINESE.ini ;FILE=SIMPLE_UltraNet.ini ``` the bolded parts don't seemingly match the actual strings in the English interface. ![:confused1:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/confused1.gif) But I still think that this tool has not the "flipping the bit" capability. ![:unsure:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/unsure.png) > Wonko is "The Man", .... Naah :smile:, he is "The Finder". :wink: The Man: [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Man](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Man "External link") ![:unsure:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/unsure.png) Thanks for the nice words, though. :smile:
From what I can get, there are TWO main "branches". The thingies numbered 2.1xx are actual "manufacturer tools". The thingies numbered (currently)v4.xxx and with either "ultranet" or "cardsorting" or "flashsort" appear like an independently developed tool. It is exactly like flashing firmware in this case ![:w00t:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/w00t.gif) , so it is VERY dangerous to do anything without having found the docs, and, as you have fopund yourself, not only the sources are mainly Chinese and Russian, but also - as always in these cases - there is a "background noise" from all the people that don't have the faintest idea of what they are talking about but anyway post/write something. It is very difficult in these cases to use the sieve to let the unimportant or plainly wrong info fall down and keep only the "good" ones :wink: . ![:cheers:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/cheers.gif) Wonko

forumNotes.author: ambralivio
forumNotes.content:
@ Zoso,  

as an additional resource, you can browse the forum in FlashBoot.ru (with a translation utility).  

I found (section SSS controller) a few threads there, talking about Kingston sticks.  

Anyway, after studying all the available/possible documentation on the matter, I think that there will come, at a certain point, the time for making some practical "experimentation" on your stick, **clearly at your own risk !!!!!!!**   

But I agree with you that there's an absolute need to study as much as possible, before going on the practical path.  

ambralivio

forumNotes.author: Zoso
forumNotes.content:
about a flipped bit.. when the bit has been flipped, is the "safely remove hardware" option no longer available? can you still eject a flashdrive after it has a flipped bit?
> It seems like the babelfish translation of the SIMPLE_Ultranet.ini, > which is clearly the translation in Chinese of the interface, just remove the ; before "SIMPLE_UltraNet.ini" in MP6690.ini: > > ``` > [LANGUAGE] > > ;FILE=CHINESE.ini > > ;FILE=SIMPLE_UltraNet.ini > ``` > > the bolded parts don't seemingly match the actual strings in the English interface. ![:eek:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/eek.gif) > But I still think that this tool has not the "flipping the bit" capability. ![:confused1:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/confused1.gif) > >
>
I noticed when starting the program that an alert box pops up that says "file MP6690.ini not found" even though this file is in the directory so there is another complication in this due to the translation.
I would like this to work for me because the only other large capacity flashdrive I have is a sandisc U3 which may be even more complicated to use in this fashion. it is proving to be more complicated than it is worth to me since I am not a computer technician by trade. I just like to know how things work and making them be the most useful but I dont actually have a real need for a "James Bond" flashdrive other than intresting hobby. I have to say, with each learning exersize I gain more and more respect for chinese and russian peoples. this technology seems to be well documented by them. I am also curious why the chinese seem to want the CDROM (cdfs) partition so badly on flashdrives? I havnt found what they are using it for yet. I think they may be running live OS from there. what do they use it for? one of my thoughts about the U3 is maybe it is possible to run a virtual machine from there that does not require installation or reboot on the host system to function. this is what I would like to have but I am not able to use a VM to its full capabilities yet as I have only just started learning about them. I searched (briefly) for english documentation on ultranet.com.cn with no luck so far. one of the programs had a .pdf manual/instruction but it was chinese. thanks

forumNotes.author: Wonko the Sane
forumNotes.content:
> about a flipped bit.. when the bit has been flipped, is the "safely remove hardware" option no longer available? can you still eject a flashdrive after it has a flipped bit? > Well, can you "still" safely eject a USB hard disk? ![:cheers:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/cheers.gif) :wink: I am thinking a bit on the issue from a different viewpoint ![:D](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/biggrin.png) Could it be you have a "frankenflash"? ![:ph34r:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/scared9.gif) (code name for "fake USB sticks") I seem to find a number of reports about the "real" Kinston Data Traveler's using Skymedi chips... ![:unsure:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/unsure.png)
Where did you get that stick from? I mean like local shop, e-bay, other online shop, etc.... There is evidence that Kingston however uses at least both chip manufacturers, so it may well be barking up a completely wrong tree. Can you check: [http://translate.goo...8O4PPWdQ0NjPSyA](http://translate.googleusercontent.com/translate_c?ie=UTF8&rurl=translate.google.it&sl=ru&tl=en&twu=1&u=http://www.flashboot.ru/forum/index.php%3FPHPSESSID%3Dhimod8dvn1vkg9o3dnk3qk3gi3%26topic%3D3442.0&usg=ALkJrhitLBuCQzKW62t8O4PPWdQ0NjPSyA "External link") And: [http://translate.goo...yh3rDg#msg26576](http://translate.googleusercontent.com/translate_c?ie=UTF8&rurl=translate.google.it&sl=ru&tl=en&twu=1&u=http://www.flashboot.ru/forum/index.php%3FPHPSESSID%3Dhimod8dvn1vkg9o3dnk3qk3gi3%26topic%3D2757.msg26576&usg=ALkJrhhXXEYBEHGoQUYvUeR2pAb6yh3rDg#msg26576 "External link")
![:cheers:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/cheers.gif) Wonko

forumNotes.author: steve6375
forumNotes.content: I have written a small tutorial on using ChipGenius and an MP tool - it shows you how you can 'flip the bit' for a removable/Fixed UFD. Of course it depends on the capabilities of the tool that you find for your particular controller. HTH .The page is here [http://sites.google....usb-flash-drive](https://sites.google.com/site/rmprepusb/tutorials/repair-your-usb-flash-drive "External link")

forumNotes.author: Wonko the Sane
forumNotes.content:
> I have written a small tutorial on using ChipGenious and ***an*** MP tool - it shows you how you can 'flip the bit' for ***a*** removable/Fixed UFD.  
Sure ![:D](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/biggrin.png), that is for the UT163/165.  

It has a rather clear selection for "Disk Type".  

This SSS is a completely different beast. ![:cheers:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/cheers.gif)  

![:ph34r:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/scared9.gif)  
Wonko

forumNotes.author: ambralivio
forumNotes.content:
> about a flipped bit.. when the bit has been flipped, is the "safely remove hardware" option no longer available? can you still eject a flashdrive after it has a flipped bit?  

I do think the option is independent from the stick being removable or fixed (local disk).  

I checked with mine (Lexar, fixed) and the option is still active. ![:D](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/biggrin.png)   

ambralivio

forumNotes.author: Zoso
forumNotes.content:
> I am thinking a bit on the issue from a different viewpoint ![:dubbio:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/dubbio.gif) > Could it be you have a "frankenflash"? ![:ph34r:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/scared9.gif) (code name for "fake USB sticks") > > I seem to find a number of reports about the "real" Kinston Data Traveler's using Skymedi chips... ![:unsure:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/unsure.png) > >
> > Where did you get that stick from? > > I mean like local shop, e-bay, other online shop, etc.... > > There is evidence that Kingston however uses at least both chip manufacturers, so it may well be barking up a completely wrong tree. > > Can you check: > [http://translate.goo...8O4PPWdQ0NjPSyA](http://translate.googleusercontent.com/translate_c?ie=UTF8&rurl=translate.google.it&sl=ru&tl=en&twu=1&u=http://www.flashboot.ru/forum/index.php%3FPHPSESSID%3Dhimod8dvn1vkg9o3dnk3qk3gi3%26topic%3D3442.0&usg=ALkJrhitLBuCQzKW62t8O4PPWdQ0NjPSyA "External link") > > And: > [http://translate.goo...yh3rDg#msg26576](http://translate.googleusercontent.com/translate_c?ie=UTF8&rurl=translate.google.it&sl=ru&tl=en&twu=1&u=http://www.flashboot.ru/forum/index.php%3FPHPSESSID%3Dhimod8dvn1vkg9o3dnk3qk3gi3%26topic%3D2757.msg26576&usg=ALkJrhhXXEYBEHGoQUYvUeR2pAb6yh3rDg#msg26576 "External link") > >
> > ![:cheers:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/cheers.gif) > Wonko I got this localy from a reputable source. it has the laser engraved numbers that match so I think its good, it will hold 16gb of data. if its counterfiet then when I opened it up I probably would have found some obscure chipset, no? > I do think the option is independent from the stick being removable or fixed (local disk). > > I checked with mine (Lexar, fixed) and the option is still active. ![:thumbsup:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/thumbsup.gif) > > ambralivio thanks for checking and the reply. Ive looked through several of these ultranet programs for this sss6690 and searched/translated alot of pages looking for more clues. I found mention of making it appear as fixed but no details as to how to do so. Im gonna put this project on the back burner for now because it is consuming more time than I can justify for the benfit gained if successful. I have a smaller 4gb flashdrive that has the same issue so I may dig into that one and see if I can flip its bit instead. I also have a sandisc 16gb U3 that is still original, not sure if its possible to flip the bit on that one either but it should be easier to find out about than this one. thanks again for all the input on this subject. I will post back here when I get more bit flipping info.

forumNotes.author: ambralivio
forumNotes.content:
> Im gonna put this project on the back burner for now because it is consuming more time than I can justify for the benfit gained if successful. I have a smaller 4gb flashdrive that has the same issue so I may dig into that one and see if I can flip its bit instead.  

I consider yours as a really wise decision. :smile:   
I'm glad to read this; clearly my initial recommendations worked..........  
![:thumbup:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/thumbup.gif)   
If I were you I wouldn't "sacrifice" an expensive stick for a task with uncertain results ![:frusty:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/frusty.gif) .  
At least, I'd make some "easy-to-make" exercise before, but with a very low cost stick accepting the related risk.  

Besides, I'd not use such an expensive, large capacity, stick for a process which will subject it to a lot of read/write cycles.  

ambralivio
